newsitem.title: USA: Guyanor ending French Guiana production.
newsitem.headline: Guyanor ending French Guiana production.

text.p: Guyanor Resources SA said its subsidiary, Societe de Travaux Publics et de Mines Auriferes en Guyane, or Sotrapmag, is discontinuing alluvial gold production in French Guiana.

Guyanor, and Golden Star Resources Ltd through its 69 percent interest in Guyanor, expect to incur a fourth quarter charge from the write-down of fixed assets and capitalized costs related to the mining operations and for severance and other costs related to the ending of production.
As of September 30, Sotrapmag had $3.2 million of net book value for fixed assets, equipment and inventories.
Guyanor said it expects some of Sotrapmag's assets will be used in the ongoing exploration at the Paul-Isnard project area and will not be subject to the write-down.
The amount of severance and other costs are contingent on negotiations with the workers and the French government.
Guyanor estimates those costs to be between $400,000 and $800,000 and said it also expects to incur operating losses of $800,000 during the shut-down process.

Noting Sotrapmag has had operating losses since its acquisition in 1994, Guyanor said consultants engaged in 1996 concluded that without a significant capital investment to increase production, changes in work practices and a reduction in fuel taxes, the operation could not achieve profitability.

It said 1996 exploration efforts identified several target areas which hold potential to establish near surface mining reserves. Guyanor has budgeted $1.0 million in 1997 for prospecting activities aimed at quantifying a near-surface mineralized inventory at the Paul-Isnard project area.

This program is in addition to the hard rock exploration planned for 1997 which will be funded by Asarco Inc and LaSource Developpement SA, the company's partners at the Paul-Isnard project area. ((-- Jim Brumm 212-859-1710.))
